Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We dug the pit on a small steep north-facing slope near the duck pass trail to get an idea on similar slopes and look into the facet layer that has been an issue this season. The bottom of the pit was uneven rocky terrain so each test had a slightly different depth (Variable by about 15cm in spots), but I will be representing all of the issues found with a consistent depth of 102cm. This slope looked to have seen multiple different wind loading events throughout the storm cycles of the year.

Läsida som samlat drevsnö senaste dygnet. Översta lagrets tjocklek och hårdhet varierar mycket i området. 10 m ifrån profilen är det översta flaket något hårdare (4F) med god sprickutbredning och ca 35 cm tjockt. HS varierar mellan 30-130 cm i området.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized
Pit dug in a Ski Area

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We did a Loaded PST. It was loaded with 10cm of snow and we let the snow sit for 60 minutes. It was 1F- when we came back. Results: +10cm Loaded PST 20/100 End on Dec 11 Facets at 37cm

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Poor pit location
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Upper areas wind scoured, lower areas wind loaded from different system. Bottom 10-40 cm's greatly affected by rough terrain and plant growth, but uniformly showing faceting and weakness. Tests were done where there was no branch interference. Ground was very rough and test results appear slightly higher than facet layer on chart. Both tests failed on facet layer.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The Solstice crust exists on all slopes below about 10,000 feet. On all south slopes and most east slopes this is a sun or temperature crust. A fragile rime crust exists on Northeast through North through Northwest and is now buried under today's new snow.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Watch Out! With the warming event in the past 24hrs, natural avalanches were observed on various terrain above 35 degrees between 6000 and 8000 feet. Signs of previous wind effect from Sunday

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Seems to have been a bit of an inversion today. Trees actively shedding snow, sticker skiing in tree line. Better snow on open NW/N/NE slopes. Facet layers seemed much more reactive in lower elevation hasty pit/ CT aprox 6900FT N aspect. Some results from graupel layer aprox 11 CM From surface that was present in upper pit (8200) but was not found in the lower pit. No sign of propagation in upper pit via CT, ECT and ski cuts.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Първи профил за сезона на избраната локация за следене на снежната покривка на т.н. полигон за снежни профили. 90-100 см снежна покривка на 2200 м н.в., стабилна и добре трансформирала основа, непритеснителен температурен градиент. Притеснителни слоеве към момента: - заровени едри кристали от валеж (иглички) на 15.12. - ледена кора с 2 см сограшица под нея (вероятно от 10.12.) Интензивен растеж на повърхностна скреж/слана, което може да се превърне в проблемен слой, ако бъде заровен.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: - Simple test pit, just to check out what will become the base layer for this year's snowpack - South facing slopes had numerous sluff/point release avalanches that released down to the bed surface; this is due to recent warm temps and no new snow in two weeks - North facing slopes are healthy but have a surface hoar layer on top that varied from large crystals in treed areas to smaller .1 size crystals at higher elevations (above 1700m)

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Läficka i TL. Brant ostsluttning.

4cm new snow past 24hrs. 16cm past 72hrs. Though upper layers at 83 and 76 cms are more reactive in compression test, they did not propogate as snow above has not formed cohesive slab yet. Persistent weak layer at 29cms did not show itself in tests as it gains strength. However this weak layer is of greatest concern at the moment, as it may be easier to trigger in shallower snowpack or certain terrein features in the area (note temp profile at this location). Also, wind has been present during storms and nearby wind slabs are also of primary concern in the area on leeward slopes above 7800 feet.

15cm new snow in past 24 hrs. High winds as storm arrived yesterday, but currently light breeze and very light snowfall; sky obstructed. Pit in NE location around 7300' . Though this NE location has a 2cm melt freeze crust, southern aspects has supportable sun crust, and westerly aspects are shallow (>30cm).

Collecting baseline snowpack data near Ripinsky Weather Station after the historic Dec 2nd rain event. Widespread surface hoar and near surface facets, also three distinct crusts (Nov 8.. Nov 13., Dec 2.).

We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug on open shaded slope below treeline. PST @ 35 cm had SF into upper facet layer that then propagated to column end. Freezing rain event created crust on top of old near surface facets which are still weak. This looks like a developing PWL to be named the Dec 11 facet layer.

A weak and shallow snowpack exists in this elevation band along the Sierra Crest. The faceting process has accelerated over the last week or so with multiple areas now showing unsupportable conditions.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This was dug in an isolated deeper patch of wind blown snow, while most of the ridge is scoured to rock from the strong E winds. While some density changes were present, margins between layers were nebulous and the pack seemed well consolidated. The layer of concern is not that concerning, but it is a bit softer than its surroundings.
